Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2010 08:13PM gfbaker wrote: I had AC first and definately needed the Emend.  My first treatment I didn't get it and was dryheaving the very same evening. With the Emend on my next treatment, no issues whatsoever. I then had taxol and didn't need anything. The red devil's the real nasty one, but cytoxin can cause problems too sometimes. If money is an issue and you are brave, you can try the first one without and see how it goes. They can always prescribe it later if needed.  Good luck, chemo is not fun but it is doable.
Posts.Title: Emend kelnied Shanagirl

Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2010 12:26PM gfbaker wrote: I didn't wear a mask either, very serious about the handwashing and tried to stay away from big crowds when I could. I don't know how many germs we really breathe in, mostly transfer from hands into mouth & eyes, so maybe buy some fabulous gloves to wear through the season.
Posts.Title: masks nora_az lago

Posts.Content: Oct 31, 2011 08:53PM gfbaker wrote: Teakay, If you decide to do the "red devil" think about getting a port if it has not already been suggested. Adriamycin can really eat up your veins, and if you have had lymph node removal then you are probably down to one arm for future draws. I did AC then Taxol and had a port. It really is not so bad and my veins are still good. Also, ask about Emend, its a nausea drug that can really help. My first dose I didn't get it and I was a pukey sick mess for 3 days. With it, tired, not hungry but stomach was calm. Expensive as all heck but insurance should cover it. Hugs, Gayle
Posts.Title: Red devil or not? Teakay sarasowise

Posts.Content: Jul 12, 2010 07:50PM gfbaker wrote: What a tough decision you have to make. I already had my kids so that was easy. A couple of things to consider/debate. Chemo usually does put you in early meno, but you can come out of it, as I did after a year. And I don't think you can take tamox while you are pregnant, so you would have to go without further treatment until you get pregnant and have your baby. I had my kids close together, and when my 2nd was 10 months old, I was diagnosed. I am convinced that having 2 kids close together (19 months apart) was what made my cancer go crazy - I'm er/pr+ too. Some women who find out that they have cancer & pregnant can do chemo after the 1st trimester. I don't know if this is something you can consider too. I would find an onc/gyn and discuss all your options so you can make the best decision for yourself. Good luck!
Posts.Title: Chemo or No Chemo Truly Cant Decide jhalvors cookiegal

Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2011 04:48PM gfbaker wrote: Hi Deb, Sorry you are having to deal with all of this. The good news is you should be able to weight train again. In fact, the latest studies indicate better control of lymphadema with weight training and having strong arms. But right now, you need to take it easy and work on getting the swelling down. I wore special garments, kind of like wrapping, to get the swelling down, compression garments only hold you where you are. I wouldn't even buy one just yet until you get to a good stable arm, ie as close to your other arm as they see possible. The LE PT should teach you how to massage your lymph system and give you gentle stretches to resolve the cording. Once you have that, you can work up from there.

Posts.Title: Really crappy news :-(((( konakat pee

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2010 04:46PM gfbaker wrote: Ladyinwaiting, I am sorry you are having to go through this at such a young age. First remember that most lumps are benign. Like only 1 in 10 women who get a diagnostic mammo have cancer. Getting yourself checked is smart, and will hopefully be benign. You shouldn't just get a letter in the mail. This is a diagnostic exam, not a routine, and so they will call it over to your gyn who ordered it, and then they will call you or have you come in to discuss. As for the genetic thing, your mom's onc can't & won't discuss another patient's records, even if it is your mom. What you can do, following your mammo is make an appointment with a genetic councelor. They can discuss your risk factor, and if it is high enough, then your insurance should pay for you to get tested for BRCA 1/2. Let us know how it goes for you.
Posts.Title: YOUNG & REPULSED ladyinwaiting gfbaker

Posts.Content: Aug 7, 2012 03:04PM gfbaker wrote: I'm sorry your team hasn't helped in the way you need. Have you looked into a cancer social worker? They are through hospitals, are free, and are there to help you navigate the system, support and all. Mine helped a great deal, even lead a support group herself. I also went to an integrative naturopath while in treatment, and they were very concerned with how I was doing, treating all of me. They were part of the hospital, exclusively worked with cancer patients in tandem with your onc. My appointments lasted 30 minutes or better, directly with the doc. Both were great for me & I'd recommend finding one or both in your area. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Help! Friend's Onc said she doesn't need steroids during Taxol. cs34 Lilah

Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2010 04:31AM gfbaker wrote: Cloud, Your lashes are going to fall out for a while. It is that they are now on the same growth cycle and shed right around the same time. I finished chemo 10/08 and it is still happening to me. Supposedly in time they will shift around the shed cycle as they used to be. One day I will get up and try to put on mascara only to find out that there are only 5 lashes to paint. I started using false lashes until mine grow back in. By the way, I totally was fine with my bald head. It was during summer so it felt nice, and walked around my neighborhood nary a scarf. Though in Oregon it is pretty easy to do. Gayle

My arm is now smaller than it was the last time I went in (I do have mild LE) and my PT said that with some conditioning, she wants to wean me off wearing my sleeve all the time and just for when I am exercising, etc. Its not that big a deal but I am so happy to hear this!! Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2012 08:04PM gfbaker wrote: One thing to add: I had my eyelashes & brows fall out after chemo too. They came back, but for about 8 months they were all on the same growth schedule, and so every 4-5 weeks they would fall out again. After about 8 months they moved back to a scattered shed pattern and are happily normal. So if you see them fall out again don't panic.

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2010 04:55PM gfbaker wrote: I would get a second opinion. 37 and grade 3 means you need to do all you can in case any got away (no node involvement doesn't necessarily free and clear). I was 38 when I was diagnosed and we didn't even bother with oncotype. My understanding is that it is not an effective test for those under 40. It is not an easy decision to make, but getting more info so you can make an informed decision for yourself is a good thing. Best of luck with the rest of your treatment, what ever that may be.
Posts.Title: StageIIA, Oncotype 17- NO CHEMO, Are you Agree? yunlee72 ColoGal

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2010 04:46PM gfbaker wrote: My cancer center has an integrative medicine department which has massage therapists who know how to properly massage someone during/just out of treatment. Maybe there is something like that in your area? If not, a massage therapist who is trained in pregnancy massage might be a good choice because they know how to adjust massage well. I get a massage every month - I consider it a necessity. Best of luck finding someone who meets your needs!
Posts.Title: Full Body massage RegulJ gfbaker

Posts.Content: Nov 2, 2010 07:09PM gfbaker wrote: I did 4 rounds of AC then 4 taxol, and I had a little peach fuzz left but mostly bald. I think that if they add the red devil in your next treatment, the rest of your hair will fall out at that point. My hair took 7 full days to fall out, and I looked really weird until it was all gone, so I was glad to go bald. But it did start growing back in during taxol. My leg hair kept growing all through treatment, so you just never know what is going to happen.
